For instance, the series from which Hunters in the Snow derives, The Seasons (1565) is divided into six paintings, five of which remain extant. “If a division of the year into six pictures seems strange initially,” Sabine Pénot and Elke Oberthaler write, “this proves to have been a common way of diving the annual cycle in the Netherlands during the period, as early spring and spring and early summer and midsummer were differentiated. The year’s inherently cyclic character relativizes the discussion around the ‘correct’ order of the pictures – which painting represents the beginning and which the end of the series” (214). Much the same may be said about the structure of Between Dog and Wolf, in which the poetic chapters trace the development of seasonal changes, while everything exists in an in-between state (seasons, characters’ identities, etc.). It is also worth noting that, as in Sokolov’s text where strict adherence to geographical reality is not observed, the landscapes depicted in the Seasons paintings are not accurate: “These so-called ‘mixed landscapes’ combine memories of the Alps with typically Flemish motifs” (229). There is something to be said about the way Sokolov, like Bruegel develops a “sheer inexhaustible richness of detail” that inevitably leads to “the limits of visual perception and linguistic representation” (215). One particular detail of the painting, apparently not described by Sokolov in the novel, feels relevant: “Thick icicles have claimed the mill wheel at the right edge and brought it to a halt, as though time itself has frozen” (228). Indeed, time and therefore the characters feel stuck in the world of Between Dog and Wolf.

intertextuality intratextuality structure foreign
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion foreign intratextuality
Yegor

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion foreign intratextuality
that dame

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
hang himself

It becomes a pattern that men who spend time with the Dame return depleted and soon after commit suicide.

theme
They started cheerin him up: You’ll always have time to hang yourself, better let’s chat

This conversation and the hunters’ dare to Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr to hang himself after his time with the Dame is picked up in chapter 10 (R222/E127–128) and also appears in Note XXXI (R268/E208).

intratextuality
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion foreign intratextuality explanatory
Overbrowears

A reference to the Russian expression “Выше лба уши не растут” meaning that one has limits to what they can do.

phraseologism translation
sawmill

Mentioned by the narrator in the next chapter (R213/E111).

intratextuality
bet

They are now betting that he will not hung himself.

explanatory
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion foreign intratextuality
Fyodor

The name changes, yet again, to Fyodor. Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion foreign intratextuality
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intratextuality character folklore
mussels

In chapter 1, Ilya describes his love of mussels — a sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

motif intratextuality symbol religion theme bible
nightingale

According to Peter Tate: “A small member of the warbler family, which has russet upper parts, a broad tail, and is grey-brown below. Its preferred habitat is deciduous woods with dense undergrowth. It is notable for its beautiful song whose notes rise and fall in succession. Contrary to popular belief, nightingales don’t just sing at night, but their song is more difficult to distinguish in daylight hours owing to competition from other birds and everyday ambient noise” (81). José Vergara writes: “the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family” (“Flap” 364–365). The characters of Sokolov’s novel play out this plot with Ilya seeking out his missing lover Orina and their son Yakov. Animal-human motif.

motif intertextuality
adder’s tongue

A fern said to resemble a serpent’s tongue. Plant motif.

motif
is spinnin cock-and-bull stories

Boguslawski translates literally this Russian set expression meaning “to tell lies or extremely unusual things.” Here, it suggests it is singing.

phraseologism translation
factory

According to Sokolov, this “button factory” exists only in Ilya’s imagination (personal communication, August 25, 2023).

explanatory
Slush

Ostanin suggests comparing this stream to the Zhizha, a small tributary of the Moscow River (63).

location
mussels

In chapter 1, Ilya describes his love of mussels — a sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

motif intratextuality symbol religion theme bible
dory

Boat motif.

motif
Y

The original is ты (informal you).

translation
mussels

In chapter 1, Ilya describes his love of mussels — a sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

motif religion bible symbol intratextuality theme
cleverly fashioned in the manner of beggars’ palms

Ilya describes mussels as beggars’ hands.

explanatory symbol
the thing lyin in plain sight is lyin there hidden better than anythin

According to Sokolov, this is simply a bit of “folk wisdom”: “it’s considered that if you want to hide a certain object, then put it in plain sight, among ordinary, everyday objects” (personal communication, August 25, 2023).

explanatory
debit

Ilya uses an accounting term to warn Pozhilykh against taking his hidden pearls.

language
Carl stole from Clara a coral tiara

Boguslawski translates here the famous Russian tongue-twister “Карл у Клары украл кораллы, а Клара у Карла украла кларнет” (Karl stole from Klara coral, but Klara stole from Carl a clarinet).

translation intertextuality language
a certain day, You know, will come

Vaguely Biblical phrasing: “A day is going to come.” Alludes to Judgement Day. Ilya is associated with the prophet Elijah throughout the novel. Boguslawski also notes a resonance with Nikolai Dobroliubov’s essay “When Will the Read Day Finally Come” (1862) (“Annotations” 245). Read the Russian original here.

bible religion intertextuality
barges

A non-self-propelled barge that is carried by other ships. Boat motif.

motif
beevaks

Bivouacs.

register/style
dory

Boat motif.

motif
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intratextuality character folklore
the grinder has mush in his stockpot

Boguslawski translates literally the expression used in the original, a variation of “na myakine ne provedyosh,” meaning a sharp cookie, no fooling that one. Here, Ilya asks Pozhilykh whether he hoped that Ilya would have chaff or the remains of threshing in his pot (i.e., have mush for brains).

translation phraseologism
pretend to snuggle with manure

He only pretends to be poor.

explanatory
bright future

A key phrase in Soviet ideology regarding the glorious future that the USSR would achieve.

Russia phraseologism explanatory
dinghy

Boat motif.

motif
Beyond the Wolf

In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

translation location setting Russia
someday we will get even to the other side

That is, we will die.

theme explanatory
stern

The rear end of a ship. Boat motif.

motif
mint

Perennial herbs. According to Gretchen Scoble and Ann Field, mint “is named after the Greek water nymph Minthe, who was changed into the herb by the jealous goddess Proserpina when Pluto cast lustful looks her way. Some time later mint was dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and in the Middle Ages, mint was used to perfume synagogues. Spearmint, peppermint, corn mint, and pennyroyal all have, to a greater or lesser degree, a fresh, cleansing aroma and a pleasing flavor” (72). Plant motif.

motif
lungwort

A perennial, flowering plant. Plant motif.

motif
hemlock

A poisonous flowering plant. Plant motif.

motif
unwanted odor

Ostanin notes (63) that it is the smell of dead bodies, since this vessel carries the dead.

explanatory theme
at the last moment You started whinin, refused to go

Pozhilykh did not die.

explanatory
bequeeted

Bequeathed.

register/style
dory

Boat motif.

motif
It’s as simple as steamin turnips, but it allows us to launch all kinds of provisions or foodstuffs more than once

As Elena Kravchenko notes, this “recycling” practice is central to the novel on many levels: “Its eternal cyclical progression is manifest not only on the literary level of Iakov’s intertextual recycling, but also on the literal level in a portrayal of the material recycling in Il’ia’s skaz. Zaitil’shchina, the main setting of Il’ia’s story as indicated by the titles of his narratives, represents its embodiment” (The Prose 69).

structure
as simple as steamin turnips

Boguslawski translates literally the Russian set expression: проще пареной репы (easy as pie, like rolling off a barrel, easy as can be). Originates with the ease with which turnips are prepared.

phraseologism translation
miller

Miller, related to the term mel’nitsa (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between “milling” and “pastries.” Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

character intratextuality theme language
wandrin cripple

The word used in the original, kalika, indicates blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin caligae, Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. (Miller 27–28). Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 9 (R214/E112), chapter 10 (R223/E129), and chapter 11 (R230/E141). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif translation intertextuality intratextuality Russia foreign
miller

Miller, related to the term mel’nitsa (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between “milling” and “pastries.” Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

character intratextuality theme language
Malokulebyakovo

A town on the banks of the river.

location
kulebyak

Сoulibiac (кулебяка, kulebiaka): a Russian pie pastry (pirog) typically filled with salmon or sturgeon, rice or buckwheat, hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, onions, and dill.

Russia explanatory
Mylomukomolovo

Much as the characters’ names shift, so, too, do the names of the town.

explanatory location
Mykomulolomovo

Much as the characters’ names shift, so, too, do the names of the town.

location explanatory
we were called Mykomulolomovo long ago

A possible hint to the habit of modifying toponyms in the Soviet epoch.

Russia
Mykomulolomovo

Much as the characters’ names shift, so, too, do the names of the town.

location explanatory
Milokurelemovo

Much as the characters’ names shift, so, too, do the names of the town.

location explanatory
mallow we never kulelemed

A play on the name of the town, of course, dividing up malo (little) and kulyomali (did poorly).

language pun
miller

Miller, related to the term mel’nitsa (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between “milling” and “pastries.” Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

character intratextuality theme language
Siberian angora

The Turkish Angora is a breed of domestic cat. The Siberian breed is Animal motif.

motif
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting
dory

Boat motif.

motif
after the sunset

That is, between dog and wolf.

theme time
forcast

Forecast.

register/style
flat-bottom boat

Boat motif.

motif
Cheremis

The pre-revolutionary term for the Mari peoples. The Mari live along the Volga and Kama Rivers and in the Mari El, Bashkortostan, and Tatarstan Republics. Martina Napolitano writes, “In 1968 Sokolov eventually chose to register as a non-attending student (zaochnoe obuchenie) due to his frustration with city life. He moved to the village of Morki in the Mari Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic with Taisiia Suvorova, a fellow student and his first wife until 1974. He then concluded his studies in 1971, having already started to collaborate with the prestigious “Literaturnaia gazeta” mainly submitting book and art reviews. His last article published on the pages of this weekly magazine, titled Poznat’ prirodu tetivy (Knowing the nature of the bowstring), was dedicated to Mari poets. In this text, Sokolov expressed his appreciation for the first translations that appeared in Russian, but also included general reflections concerning poetry and art” (Sasha Sokolov). In a review with Kira Sapgir, Sokolov stated the following: ““I believed that the work of a journalist would lead me faster to real prose. And since you can write more freely not in the central newspaper, but in a peripheral one, I switched to the correspondence department and left for the Mari Republic. I worked in a district newspaper, in a village, a hundred kilometers from Yoshkar-Ola. I was 22 years old. My appearance there — “a man from the capital” — was somewhat stunning. As a result, I wasn’t bothered, and I could write whatever I wanted, I could even afford to experiment. I wrote mainly essays about people: I took the surname, first name, and patronymic of a person, and invented his whole life. These were, in fact, stories, and the hero could be a gamekeeper, forester, innkeeper, anyone. These were short story-essays written in rhythmic prose: if you like, close to the style of Andrei Bely, although at that time I hadn’t read anything about him or his work itself. The first time I read Bely was here, abroad, and I was surprised: it looks similar” (“V ‘Russkoi mysli’” 11).

Russia foreign
Vasya

Diminutive form of the name Vasilii.

character register/style
I saw among the damages of fate the single singular ray of light—the trap net full of holes

The only good thing that happened to him in his desperate life is having a fishing net.

explanatory
dory

Boat motif. Although translated always as “dory,” in the original here we do not find “chelnok,” but “doshchenik,” a flat-bottomed vessel with a sail and oars.

motif translation
dory

Boat motif.

motif
uke

Mari: no, there is not. Martina Napolitano writes, “In 1968 Sokolov eventually chose to register as a non-attending student (zaochnoe obuchenie) due to his frustration with city life. He moved to the village of Morki in the Mari Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic with Taisiia Suvorova, a fellow student and his first wife until 1974. He then concluded his studies in 1971, having already started to collaborate with the prestigious “Literaturnaia gazeta” mainly submitting book and art reviews. His last article published on the pages of this weekly magazine, titled Poznat’ prirodu tetivy (Knowing the nature of the bowstring), was dedicated to Mari poets. In this text, Sokolov expressed his appreciation for the first translations that appeared in Russian, but also included general reflections concerning poetry and art” (Sasha Sokolov). In a review with Kira Sapgir, Sokolov stated the following: “I believed that the work of a journalist would lead me faster to real prose. And since you can write more freely not in the central newspaper, but in a peripheral one, I switched to the correspondence department and left for the Mari Republic. I worked in a district newspaper, in a village, a hundred kilometers from Yoshkar-Ola. I was 22 years old. My appearance there — ‘a man from the capital’ — was somewhat stunning. As a result, I wasn’t bothered, and I could write whatever I wanted, I could even afford to experiment. I wrote mainly essays about people: I took the surname, first name, and patronymic of a person, and invented his whole life. These were, in fact, stories, and the hero could be a gamekeeper, forester, innkeeper, anyone. These were short story-essays written in rhythmic prose: if you like, close to the style of Andrei Bely, although at that time I hadn’t read anything about him or his work itself. The first time I read Bely was here, abroad, and I was surprised: it looks similar” (“V Russkoi mysli” 11).

foreign self-reference
e-e

Mari: is present. Mari: no, there is not. Martina Napolitano writes, “In 1968 Sokolov eventually chose to register as a non-attending student (zaochnoe obuchenie) due to his frustration with city life. He moved to the village of Morki in the Mari Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic with Taisiia Suvorova, a fellow student and his first wife until 1974. He then concluded his studies in 1971, having already started to collaborate with the prestigious “Literaturnaia gazeta” mainly submitting book and art reviews. His last article published on the pages of this weekly magazine, titled Poznat’ prirodu tetivy (Knowing the nature of the bowstring), was dedicated to Mari poets. In this text, Sokolov expressed his appreciation for the first translations that appeared in Russian, but also included general reflections concerning poetry and art” (Sasha Sokolov). In a review with Kira Sapgir, Sokolov stated the following: “I believed that the work of a journalist would lead me faster to real prose. And since you can write more freely not in the central newspaper, but in a peripheral one, I switched to the correspondence department and left for the Mari Republic. I worked in a district newspaper, in a village, a hundred kilometers from Yoshkar-Ola. I was 22 years old. My appearance there — ‘a man from the capital’ — was somewhat stunning. As a result, I wasn’t bothered, and I could write whatever I wanted, I could even afford to experiment. I wrote mainly essays about people: I took the surname, first name, and patronymic of a person, and invented his whole life. These were, in fact, stories, and the hero could be a gamekeeper, forester, innkeeper, anyone. These were short story-essays written in rhythmic prose: if you like, close to the style of Andrei Bely, although at that time I hadn’t read anything about him or his work itself. The first time I read Bely was here, abroad, and I was surprised: it looks similar” (“V Russkoi mysli” 11).

foreign self-reference
e-e

Mari: is present. Martina Napolitano writes, “In 1968 Sokolov eventually chose to register as a non-attending student (zaochnoe obuchenie) due to his frustration with city life. He moved to the village of Morki in the Mari Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic with Taisiia Suvorova, a fellow student and his first wife until 1974. He then concluded his studies in 1971, having already started to collaborate with the prestigious “Literaturnaia gazeta” mainly submitting book and art reviews. His last article published on the pages of this weekly magazine, titled Poznat’ prirodu tetivy (Knowing the nature of the bowstring), was dedicated to Mari poets. In this text, Sokolov expressed his appreciation for the first translations that appeared in Russian, but also included general reflections concerning poetry and art” (Sasha Sokolov). In a review with Kira Sapgir, Sokolov stated the following: “I believed that the work of a journalist would lead me faster to real prose. And since you can write more freely not in the central newspaper, but in a peripheral one, I switched to the correspondence department and left for the Mari Republic. I worked in a district newspaper, in a village, a hundred kilometers from Yoshkar-Ola. I was 22 years old. My appearance there — ‘a man from the capital’ — was somewhat stunning. As a result, I wasn’t bothered, and I could write whatever I wanted, I could even afford to experiment. I wrote mainly essays about people: I took the surname, first name, and patronymic of a person, and invented his whole life. These were, in fact, stories, and the hero could be a gamekeeper, forester, innkeeper, anyone. These were short story-essays written in rhythmic prose: if you like, close to the style of Andrei Bely, although at that time I hadn’t read anything about him or his work itself. The first time I read Bely was here, abroad, and I was surprised: it looks similar” (“V Russkoi mysli” 11).

foreign self-reference
uke

Mari: no, there is not. Martina Napolitano writes, “In 1968 Sokolov eventually chose to register as a non-attending student (zaochnoe obuchenie) due to his frustration with city life. He moved to the village of Morki in the Mari Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic with Taisiia Suvorova, a fellow student and his first wife until 1974. He then concluded his studies in 1971, having already started to collaborate with the prestigious “Literaturnaia gazeta” mainly submitting book and art reviews. His last article published on the pages of this weekly magazine, titled Poznat’ prirodu tetivy (Knowing the nature of the bowstring), was dedicated to Mari poets. In this text, Sokolov expressed his appreciation for the first translations that appeared in Russian, but also included general reflections concerning poetry and art” (Sasha Sokolov). In a review with Kira Sapgir, Sokolov stated the following: “I believed that the work of a journalist would lead me faster to real prose. And since you can write more freely not in the central newspaper, but in a peripheral one, I switched to the correspondence department and left for the Mari Republic. I worked in a district newspaper, in a village, a hundred kilometers from Yoshkar-Ola. I was 22 years old. My appearance there — ‘a man from the capital’ — was somewhat stunning. As a result, I wasn’t bothered, and I could write whatever I wanted, I could even afford to experiment. I wrote mainly essays about people: I took the surname, first name, and patronymic of a person, and invented his whole life. These were, in fact, stories, and the hero could be a gamekeeper, forester, innkeeper, anyone. These were short story-essays written in rhythmic prose: if you like, close to the style of Andrei Bely, although at that time I hadn’t read anything about him or his work itself. The first time I read Bely was here, abroad, and I was surprised: it looks similar” (“V Russkoi mysli” 11).

foreign self-reference
Micheas the Morasthite

Sokolov writes, “At some point I read ‘Mikhei Marafetin’ in some text. I can’t find any evidence of that now. I found two variants: Morasfitianin and Morasfitin. So, let’s change it to Morasfitin” (“Bol’shoe” 133).

intertextuality explanatory
Micheas the Morasthite taught wrong that everyone setteth a net for his brother

An allusion to Micah 7:2.

intertextuality religion bible
nunset

In the original Ilya says staritse rather than starosti (old age). A female religious elder, a nun. Also a city on the Volga in the Tver Oblast. Ostanin notes a meaning connection: Staritsa — Pozhilykh — Zhivago — Vetkhii Den’mi (Ancient of Days) (64).

Russia religion location
Fomich

Pozhilykh’s patronymic. A familiar form of address using the patronymic.

character register/style
rowboat

Boat motif. In the original, the word indicates a poor-quality boat.

motif translation
bird

Animal motif.

motif
water strider

Appears three times in the novel (R210, 221, 254/E105, 126, 185). Animal-human motif. Zlata Kocić reads the three references to water-striders in Between Dog and Wolf as metatextual commentary on the stylistic movements of the novel: what appears to be jerky and chaotic actually reveals itself to be rhythmic and intentional (379).

motif intratextuality
The rowlocks are cryin exactly like lapwings, they’re not oiled at all

Lapwings have traditionally been associated with misbehaving women (Rowland, Birds 97). José Vergara writes: “Maria/Orina is regularly correlated with deceptions and betrayal, often sexual in nature, so the reference to the lapwings has some internal logic. Her squealing evokes the folklore of the naughty birds” in key scenes throughout the novel, and the “sounds of the bird thus echo throughout the book’s architecture. Even when not physically present, Maria’s presence can be felt here, as the longing the two heroes feel for each other manifests in the creaking sounds” (“Flap” 367–368). Animal-human motif.

motif folklore
rowlocks

The device used to hold an oar in place on a boat. Boat motif.

motif
lapwings

Lapwings have traditionally been associated with misbehaving women (Rowland 97). Beryl Rowland describes the lapwing as “the most intelligent of the prophetic birds which attended King Solomon and it guarded his secrets” (97). José Vergara writes: “Maria/Orina is regularly correlated with deceptions and betrayal, often sexual in nature, so the reference to the lapwings has some internal logic. Her squealing evokes the folklore of the naughty birds” in key scenes throughout the novel (Vergara, “Flap” 367). Animal-human motif.

motif
fox

Animal motif.

motif
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting
empties

Implied: bottles. Alcohol theme.

theme
gather the disowned vessels—and right away to Sloboda

In order to get money from the empty glass bottles.

explanatory
leeches

Animal motif.

motif
crucians

Crucian carps, fish belonging to the Carassius genus and Cyprinidae family. Animal motif. This same question, as well as this general scene, first appears in chapter 1 (R157/E15). Alexander Boguslawski notes: “Sokolov increases the artistic impact of these two descriptions by combining images with skillful manipulation of the lexical material. It is easy to see the delicate modulations of the phrase about the carp, achieved by synonymic substitutions prishchurilsia – prigliadelsia and dremali – kemarli as well as by replacement of zdes’ gde by tut u nas and of ershi eti samye by mne vzbrelo vdrug” (“How Sokolov’s” 215).

motif intratextuality
ruffs

Ruffe or pope. A freshwater fish. Animal-human motif. The same word in Russian, yorsh, indicates a mixed drink with beer and vodka. Alcohol theme.

theme motif
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intratextuality intertextuality
Orina was swimmin above me

Ilya returns to the scene presented near the end of chapter 1 where he and Orina go swimming in the river.

intratextuality
like a frog

Animal-human motif.

motif
algae

Plant motif.

motif
my distant nearby

Oxymoron.

poetic device
she was teasin geese in Ilya

Orina’s body arouses Ilya. Beyond being considered a silly or stupid animal, the goose has other resonances. According to Beryl Rowland, the goose has been seen as “an erotic symbol for both sexes, because it was the bird of creation, whether in the male solar form of the gods or the female lunar form of the mother goddesses” (Birds 68). Connections between geese, sexuality, and foolishness appear several times in the novel (R154, 210, 221/E10, 106, 126). A reference to Ivan Krylov’s “Geese” (1811). Read the original here and a translation here. Animal-human motif.

motif intratextuality folklore
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intratextuality character folklore
snub nose

Also used to refer to the embodiment of death, which further links Orina with the Dame who visits the hunters and occupies for three days before they return and die by suicide.

character theme
the stick of my flesh

That is, his penis.

explanatory
mussels

In chapter 1, Ilya describes his love of mussels — a sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

motif intratextuality symbol religion theme bible
Gorynych

Usually “zmei Gorynych,” a beast resembling a snake or dragon (with three, sometimes more, heads) from Slavic mythology. This creature holds the power of fire, yet usually dwells by water. In some stories zmei Gorynych works for Koshchei, an Eastern Slavic folkloric figure comparable to Hades and whose soul (and, therefore, death) is hidden in a needle that is hidden inside an egg in a duck in a hare in a coffer buried under an oak on an island. Depicted here: Animal motif.

folklore motif intertextuality
scabiosas

A genus of the honeysuckle family, also known as pincushion flowers. Traditionally used to treat scabies. Plant motif.

motif
Before my maimin

Ilya loses a leg in an accident involving a train. Several versions of this event are told throughout the novel.

intratextuality explanatory
lonesome babe

She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

character
stitched

Various characters sew in the novel. In Yakov’s eighth poem, an oriole “resews evening into night” (R172/E39). Sewing is also mentioned in Note XVI (R200/E92). Yakov sews slippers (R274/E219). Sewing theme.

theme intratextuality
an empty tied-up pant leg

The pant leg with the missing leg.

explanatory
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
on the twentieth accordin to the Old Style, it’s Ilya’s name day

August 2 according to the New Style calendar. Ilya’s day.

time explanatory
accordin to the Old Style

The shift from the Julian calendar to the Gregorian calendar that took place in February 1918 in Soviet Russia, resulting in a 13-day loss.

time
Time—close to five

At the hour between dog and wolf.

time theme
frogs

Orina’s legs were compared to frogs a few lines above. Animal-human motif.

motif intratextuality
started croakin like insane, they sensed my mood

Pathetic fallacy: the natural world responds to Ilya’s emotions and desires throughout the novel.

poetic device
under the platform

Ilya’s outsider status is literalized as he observes the world from underneath the railroad platform. Railroad theme.

theme
so Orina took an advance a day earlier

This episode is also mentioned in chapter 14 (R258–259/E194).

intratextuality
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

theme character intertextuality intratextuality
advance

Of her salary.

explanatory
have yourself a blast

Ostanin explains that this suggests the possibility of living one’s entire life on little money (65). He also notes a borrowing from Vladimir Vysotsky’s song “Penal Battalions.” Read the lyrics in the original and in English translation here.

explanatory intertextuality music
in those tricky years

See also Chapter 6 (R194/E78).

intratextuality
acacias

Acacia trees. A self-reference to Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, in which the character Vetka Acacia appears: “как твое имя меня называют Веткой я Ветка акации я Ветка железной дороги я Вета беременная от ласковой птицы по имени Найтингейл я беременна будущим летом и крушением товарняка” (whats your name I am called Vetka [Branch] I am Vetka of the acacia I am Vetka of the railroad I am Veta pregnant by the tender bird named Nightingale I am pregnant with the coming summer and the crash of the freight train) (Shkola R11/E12). There is thus a confluence of motifs here: trains, plants, sex. Ernst and Johanna Lehner write that the acacia is “native to Egypt” and “called by the Israelites the Shittah-tree. They carried the wood of this tree in their exodus from Egypt through the desert, and later built their Tabernacle and the Arc of the Covenant from this wood to atone for their crime committed at Shittin. The wood of the acacia was considered sacred by the Hebrews” (23). Furthermore, the thorny crown of Jesus was allegedly made from acacia according to sources from the Middle East (23). Plant motif.

motif self-reference intertextuality
dried Azov sea roach

Roach served as a dried snack with drinks. Animal motif.

motif
croakers

Frogs. Animal motif.

motif
I considered turnin the clouds back

An apparent reference to Ilya’s connection to the prophet Elijah and his mastery over thunder, clouds, rain, and so on.

intertextuality religion
the hidden water in the clouds

Boguslawski translates literally this variation of the Russian set expression “темна вода во облацех,” meaning something we hardly comprehend, that is obscure.

translation phraseologism
An overturned abandoned scow was lyin there on the pebbles upside down

This scene is mentioned by Ilya in chapter 14 (R256–257/E189).

intratextuality
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intratextuality character folklore
Bugbear’s walkin, full of life, carries seven slippers: for himself, for his wife, and a slipper for each nipper

A Russian nursery rhyme “used to make children aware of their body (spine); as used here, it may indicate intimate contact between Orina and Ilya” (Boguslawski “Annotations” 245). The original goes: “Шел Бай по стене, / Нес лапти в кошеле. Детишкам по лаптишкам, / И себе, и жене.”

intertextuality theme explanatory
slippers

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
old junk

Described in chapter 10 (R220, 222/E124, 126).

intratextuality
You revealed to me your life stories, my friend says to me, so if you want— I will also tell you a few things.

This narrative—a switch to Orina’s point of view—will be picked up at the beginning of chapter 10 (R218/E121).

explanatory character intratextuality
сивухи

Cheap, poor-quality vodka. Moonshine, rotgut, raw vodka. From the Polish siwy (grey). Interestingly enough (but the reader is already acquainted with Ilya’s style and points of reference), the metaphor is created starting from an alcoholic beverage. Alcohol theme.

Дешевая водка плохого качества. Тема алкоголя. Плохоочищенная, некрепкая хлебная водка. От польского siwy (серый). Любовытно заметить (хотя читатель уже знаком со стилем Ильи и его излюбленными объектами метафор), что метафора построена на алкогольном напитке.

theme foreign poetic device
гнилья

Colloquial: rotten stuff.

Разговорное: что-то гнилое, испорченное.

register/style
злообразных обманчивых жен

That is, Orina and her multiple hypostases.

character
Сумерк длился

Again, between dog and wolf. In the world of the novel, twilight/dusk is ever-present (extends, continues), leading to all sorts of confusion. Normally, the word сумерки (twilight) is never used in the singular.

Вновь, между собакой и волком. В мире романа, сумерки вездесущи и приводят к разного рода путаницам. Обычно слово “сумерки” не употребляется в единственном числе.

theme
морок

Dialectical/dated: darkness.

Диалектическое/устаревшее: то же, что мрак (темнота).

register/style
неутишимая алчба по чистому, по незамутненной воде

An echo of the pull Ilya feels when in the river at the end of chapter 1.

Отголосок тяги, которую чувствует Илья в реке в конце главы 1.

intratextuality theme
алчба

Literary: greed, thirst, hunger.

register/style
Препоясался

Dated: to gird oneself, belt oneself, put on a belt.

Устаревшее: подпоясаться, надеть на себя пояс.

register/style
Препоясался я чем попадя и пошел, выражаясь условно, на самую глубь, юля

In this section, Ilya blurs the lines and connections between the river/water and death.

В этом отрывке Илья стирает границы и связи между рекой/водой и смертью.

theme
чем попадя

Set expression: with whatever comes to hand.

Устойчивое выражение: чем попадется под руку, всем подряд.

phraseologism
юля

Colloquial: to wriggle.

Разговорное: вертеться, крутиться.

register/style
Что есть счастье и что есть несчастие

An echo from chapter 4: “Ведь что такое несчастье и что такое счастие, когда задаться на миг? Несчастие — это если нет счастия, а счастие, Оря, это если несчастия нет” (what is unhappiness and what is happiness, if you think about it? Unhappiness is when there is no happiness, and happiness, Orya, is when there’s no unhappiness). The answer in this case is semantically the same, yet syntactically put in a different way: “happiness is when there is happiness.”

Отголосок главы 4: “Ведь что такое несчастье и что такое счастие, когда задаться на миг? Несчастие — это если нет счастия, а счастие, Оря, это если несчастия нет”. В этом случае, ответ семантически остается прежним, но сформулирован по-другому: “счастье — это когда есть счастье”.

intratextuality
несчастие

Dated/poetic: unhappiness.

Устаревшее/поэтическое: то же, что несчастье.

register/style
Вы

Ilya addresses Pozhilykh, the inspector.

Илья обращается к инспектору Пожилых.

character intratextuality
счастие

Dated/poetic: happiness. Old orthography.

Устаревшее/поэтическое: то же, что счастье.

register/style
перемелется

From the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.

От выражения: “Всё перемелется — мука будет”. Выражение темы мельницы в романе. Соколов неоднократно обыгрывает это выражение и созвучность муки (страдания) и муки (хлебопекарной).

theme phraseologism intratextuality
Отзвеним неточеными, отболим кумполами дубовыми, отдурим и отпляшем, и отчалим

Repetition of the verbal prefix ot- and general assonance of the vowel -o-.

Повтор приставки от- и ассонанс гласной о.

sound
Отзвеним неточеными, отболим кумполами дубовыми, отдурим и отпляшем, и отчалим однажды по утрию в Быгодождь

These are various methods characters adopt to reach the other bank of the river, that is: ways of dying.

structure theme character
неточеными

That is, their skates.

explanatory
кумполами дубовыми

That is, their crutches.

То есть, костылями.

explanatory
отдурим

Colloquial: to fool around, goof around.

Разговорное: дурачиться, забавляться.

register/style
отдурим и отпляшем

Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Plyaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

Хорея — двигательное расстройство из группы неврологических заболеваний. Название происходит от древнегреческого “χορεία” и используется для описания движений страдающих этой болезнью. Первый роман Соколова, “Школа для дураков”, был посвящен Вите Пляскиной, ссылаясь на пляску Святого Вита. Посмотреть видео можно здесь. Неоднократно упоминается в романе (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

intratextuality self-reference
отпляшем

Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Plyaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

Хорея — двигательное расстройство из группы неврологических заболеваний. Название происходит от древнегреческого “χορεία” и используется для описания движений страдающих этой болезнью. Первый роман Соколова, “Школа для дураков”, был посвящен Вите Пляскиной, ссылаясь на пляску Святого Вита. Посмотреть видео можно здесь. Неоднократно упоминается в романе (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

intratextuality self-reference
утрию

Dated/poetic: morning.

Устаревшее/поэтическое: утро.

time register/style
Быгодождь

That is, the people of the cemetery (the undertakers). In chapter 1, Ilya mentions the village of Bydogoshch, of which Bygodozhd’ could be an ironic variant (-dozhd’ meaning “rain”) (R158/E16). As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

То есть, люди кладбища (гробовщики). В главе 1, Илья упоминает деревню Быдогощ, ироничным вариантом названия которой может являться Быгодождь (R158/E16). Соколов мог иметь в виду польский город Быдогощ (расположен на реке Брда, подобно тому как деревни расположены у реки Итиль в романе), но он также мог ссылаться на деревню Видогощь на реке Волге, недалеко от Твери.
