Согласно легенде, город был основан братьями Быдом и Гостом на месте, показавшемся им идеальным, в том числе благодаря реке. Д. Б. Джонсон замечает, что, в то время как живые обитают в Городище, Быдогощи — дом мертвецов (Johnson, “Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

location Russia theme intratextuality setting
То-то

Colloquial: how (as in “how much!”).

Разговорное: вот (частица, употребляющаяся для выражения высшей степени чего-либо).

register/style
То-то пито будет во имя нас, то-то слез лито

Syntactical repetition and paronomasia (pito - lito).

Синтаксический параллелизм и парономазия (пито - лито).

rhythm stylistic device sound
то-то

Colloquial: how.

Разговорное: вот (частица, употребляющаяся для выражения высшей степени чего-либо).

register/style
то-то

Colloquial: how.

Разговорное: вот (частица, употребляющаяся для выражения высшей степени чего-либо).

register/style
девятый день

According to Orthodox tradition, among others, the ninth day after death is crucial, as it is on this day that the soul learns whether it will be accepted into Heaven. For that reason, the wake is traditionally held nine days after a person’s death. Bygodozhd’ could here represent the “city of death” or something similar (since when they leave for Bygodozhd’, people will drink, cry in their name on the ninth day, and so on).

Согласно православной традиции, в то числе, девятый день после смерти имеет особое значение, ведь на этот день душа получает ответ, примут ли ее на небеса. Поэтому поминки обычно длятся девять дней после смерти человека. Быгодождь здесь символизирует “город смерти” и что-то подобное (ведь когда они отправляются в Быгодождь, люди пьют, льют слезы в их имя и т. д.).

time religion explanatory
челноках

A light wooden boat. Boat motif.

Легкая деревянная лодка. Изображено ниже:

Мотив лодки.

motif
стругах

A strug. A boat used in Russia for centuries (11-18th). Designs varied but it typically had a flat bottom. Boat motif.

Russia motif
Погибель Фома

Foma Pogibel’ is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.”

Лодочник, перевозящий людей с одного берега реки на другой.

character bible religion intertextuality
грести-то гребет

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

stylistic device sound
нашего парадного обмундёра

Ilya is speaking about his funeral. Yakov will describe the same process of being dead and carted away in chapter 16 (R275–276/E221).

Илья имеет в виду свои похороны.

explanatory intratextuality theme
обмундёра

A variation of “obmundirovka,” uniform.

Вариация “обмундировки”.

register/style neologism
втихаря

Low: on the sly.

Просторечное: тайком, скрытно.

register/style
прорухи

Low: mistake, blunder. Here: snag, rip, hole, jag.

Просторечное: ошибка, оплошность. Здесь: дыра, щель.

register/style
махорины

From the expression “даже махорки не осталось” (nothing left). Brazilian tobacco, Plant motif.

От выражения “даже махорки не осталось”. Махорка — Nicotiana rustica. Изображено ниже:

motif
сетую

Literary: to complain.

Литературное: жаловаться.

register/style
станет мука́

From the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.

От выражения: “Всё перемелется — мука будет”. Выражение темы мельницы в романе. Соколов неоднократно обыгрывает это выражение и созвучность муки (страдания) и муки (хлебопекарной).

theme phraseologism intratextuality language
бродил я, трудился и выбивался из жил, обаче более бил баклухи

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
выбивался из жил

A variation of the set expression: “vybivat’sja iz sil,” meaning to get very tired because of hard work.

Вариация устойчивого выражения: выбиваться из сил (уставать от тяжелой работы).

phraseologism
обаче

Archaic: but.

Архаизм: но.

register/style archaism
бил баклухи

Set expression: to twiddle one’s thumbs (бить баклуши).

Устойчивое выражение: ничего не делать.

phraseologism
баклухи

Dialectical: a chip or block of wood used to make utensils, such as spoons.

Диалектическое: обрубок дерева или обрезок бревна, используемый для изготовления домашней утвари, например, ложек.

register/style
Взматерел

Colloquial: to reach maturity, toughen up.

Разговорное: достигнуть зрелости, возмужать.

register/style
залоснился

Usually this verb is linked with over-worn clothes. Clothing motif.

register/style motif
в обиходе

Set expression: in everyday use.

Устойчивое выражение: в повседневном употреблении.

phraseologism
хомут

Ilya describes himself as an old, over-used horse collar.

Илья сравнивает себя со старой, изношенной конной упряжкой.

character explanatory symbol
Тертый калач

Set expression: old dodger, smooth operator, old hand, an experienced person. Here, however, the metaphor from the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour) is literalized, as Ilya suggests that his troubles have been like the milling process and he has turned into a kalach.

Устойчивое выражение: стреляный воробей, бывалый, опытный человек. Здесь, однако, метафора из выражения “Всё перемелется — мука будет” приобретает буквальное значение, ведь Илья сравнивает свои невзгоды с процессом перемолки муки, которые превращают его в калач.

phraseologism theme language intratextuality symbol
калач

A traditional, rounded bread from Eastern Europe..

Традиционный круглый восточноевропейский хлеб. Изображено ниже:

explanatory Russia
вечор

Low: last evening (вчера вечером).

Просторечное: вчера вечером.

register/style
сдобою

Sdoba indicates what is added to dough in order to make it more tasty and increase its nutritional value (it could be milk, egg, dry fruits, etc.).

Слово “сдоба” указывает на добавление ингредиента, который придает выпечке вкус и повышает пищевую ценность (например, молоко, яйцо, сухофрукты и т. п.).

explanatory
треух

A warm hat with three flaps (ears + back). Clothing motif.

Теплая шапка с тремя “ушами” (наушниками и опускным задком). Изображено ниже:

Мотив одежды.

motif
пестрядинным

Made of a fabric composed by multicolored threads. Once again Ilya touches upon the theme of sewing.

Сделанное из ткани из разноцветных ниток. Илья в очередной раз затрагивает тему шитья. Тема шитья.

explanatory theme
пестрядинным путем

Sokolov identifies this as the Milky Way (“Bol’shoe” 132). Constellation-heavens motif.

Соколов определяет это как Млечный Путь (Sokolov “Bol’shoe” 132). Мотив созвездий-неба.

motif
Боженьке

Diminutive for Bog, God.

Уменьшительное для слова “Бог”.

register/style
кому

Ilya underlines that we are usually, if not always, defined as somebody (son, father, wife, etc.) in relation to somebody else. According to this “somebody else” our identity also changes (one can be both a daughter, a sister, and a mother), as identities change in the novel.

explanatory structure character
Брат и сват я кому-то, кому-то кум

Chiasmus.

Хиазм.

stylistic device rhythm
Брат и сват я кому-то, кому-то кум, а бывает, что вовсе зять — ни дать и ни взять.

Internal rhymes and rhythm.

Внутренняя рифма и ритм.

rhythm rhyme
зять — ни дать и ни взять

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

stylistic device sound
ни дать и ни взять

Set expression: no more, no less; exactly the same.

Устойчивое выражение: совершенно такой же.

phraseologism
Ныне

Literary/dated/high: now.

Литературное/устаревшее/высокий стиль: сейчас.

register/style
Ныне — пройда и бражник, валюсь в лопух, завтра — лунь я болотный, кычу совой в бору

Kh3 + Ya2 + Kh3 (with the second stress on Ya) + Ya3.

Х3 + Я2 + Х3 (со вторым ударением на “я”) + Я3.

metrical pattern
пройда

Low: scoundrel, cheat, rogue.

Просторечное: пройдоха.

register/style
бражник

Dated: reveler, drunkard. Alcohol theme. Also a hawk-moth. Animal motif.

Устаревшее: пьяница, гуляка. Тема алкоголя. Также, вид бабочек. Изображено ниже:

Мотив животных.

register/style theme motif
лопух

Burdock, Plant motif.

Изображено ниже:

Мотив растений.

motif
лунь я болотный

Marsh harrier, duck hawk. Animal-human motif.

Изображено ниже:

motif
кычу

A verb related to birds’ (owls’) singing used for example also by Sergei Esenin: “По-осеннему кычет сова” (An owl is hooting autumn-like). Read the original here.

intertextuality language
совой

The owl has long been associated with death and witchcraft (Tate 92–95). See also Armstrong 113–124, Rowland 115–120, and Chadd and Taylor 286–291. Animal-human motif. Animal motif.

motif folklore
пророк

That is to say, “I am Ilya again” (the prophet Elijah).

То есть, “Я есть Илия” (пророк).

character explanatory religion bible
когда-никогда

Set expression: sometimes, once in a while, once in a blue moon.

Устойчивое выражение: редко, час от часу.

phraseologism register/style
пестрядинным

Made of a fabric composed by multicolored threads. Once again Ilya touches upon the theme of sewing.

Сделанное из ткани из разноцветных ниток. Илья в очередной раз затрагивает тему шитья. Тема шитья.

explanatory theme
точить иду: стал Точильщик

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

stylistic device sound
Точильщик

The capital letter indicates that this is almost a title, a vocation, and echoes the word “prorok” (prophet), present in the previous period.

Заглавная буква указывает на то, что это почти титул, призвание, и перекликается со словом “пророк” в предыдущей фразе.

symbol character
кустарь

Handicrafts and craftsmen are mentioned several times in the novel (R164, 206, 220 / E28, 98, 123).

Ремесло и ремесленики неоднократно упоминаются в романе (R164, 206, 220 / E28, 98, 123).

intratextuality
Стожары-пожары

The Pleiades or Seven Sisters star cluster. In Greek mythology, the stars represented seven nymphs born of Atlas and Pleione. Also mentioned in Notes XX (R228/E138) and XXIV (R233/E145). Constellation-heavens motif.

Звездное скопление Плеяд, или Семи Сестер. Изображено ниже:

В греческой мифологии, эти звезды представляли собой семь нимф — дочерей Атланта и Плейоны. Изображено ниже:

Также упоминаются в Записке XX (R228/E138) и XXIV (R233/E145). Мотив созвездий-неба.

intertextuality motif foreign intratextuality
Стожары-пожары

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
Стожары-пожары горят, тут, по левую, — Крылобыл, косолапый стрелок

In Greek mythology, it is said that Orion, the hunter, pursued the seven sisters, which led Zeus to place the nymphs in the sky as stars. Here, the novel’s characters blur with these constellations and myths. Indeed, the “strelok” is also an allusion to the “strelets,” Sagittarius. Constellation-heavens motif.

Согласно греческой мифологии, охотник Орион преследевал семь сестер, чем вынудил Зевса поместить нимф на небо в виде звезд. Здесь, герои романа сливаются с созвездиями и мифами. В самом деле, “стрелок” в данном контексте — отсылка к Стрельцу, знаку зодиака. Мотив созвездий-неба.

intertextuality symbol motif foreign
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

intertextuality character intratextuality
косолапый

Yet another character with a physical deformity.

Очередной герой с физическим увечьем.

theme intratextuality
Медицинские Сестры

As Sokolov himself explains, “the Nurses do not correspond to the Seven Sisters” (the Pleiades). This constellation, as well as the others mentioned in this chapter (except for the Stozhary), “are the product of Ilya’s imagination” (personal communication, June 7, 2023). Constellation-heavens motif.

Сам Соколов объясняет, что “Медицинские Сестры не соответствуют Семи Сестрам”. Это созвездие, наряду с другими названными в этой главе (кроме Стожаров), “суть плоды его (Ильи) воображения” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

motif
Орина

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Орина-дурина

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
Орина-дурина и чадо ее Орион

Paronomasia (Orina-Orion).

Парономазия (Ирина - Орион).

sound stylistic device
чадо

Archaism: progeny, offspring. The mother of Orion, according to Greek mythology, was Euryale, the daughter of the king of Crete. His father was Poseidon. In Greek mythology there was however a second and better known Euryale: she was one of the Gorgons (the three sisters having snakes for hair), and she represented the sexual perversion (while her sisters represented the intellectual and the moral perversions).

Архаизм: дитя, ребенок, отпрыск. Матерью Ориона, согласно греческой мифологии, была Эвриала, дочь царя Крита. Его отцом был Посейдон. Однако в греческой мифологии присутствует и другая, более известная Эвриала — одна из Горгон (трех сестрех со змеями вместо волос), символизирующая половое извращение (тогда как ее сестры символизировали интелектуальное и моральное извращения).

register/style intertextuality archaism foreign
Орион

The great hunter from Greek mythology, a constellation found along the celestial equator, and, following the logic of the novel, Yakov, son of Orina. Moreover, scientifically Orion and Sagittarius are linked: although there is no general consensus on exactly where the Orion Arm begins, most scholars agree that this arm originates from an offshoot of the Sagittarius Arm in the outer direction. Constellation/heavens motif. As Ostanin suggests (61), it could also be a reference to the talking horse Arion, another son of Poseidon. Arion was also the name of a poet, to whom Pushkin dedicated his poem “Arion” (1827).

Великий охотник, согласно греческой мифологии, а также созвездие в области небесного экватора и, следуя логике романа, Яков — сын Орины. Более того, Орион и Стрелец связаны астрономически: хотя нет общего согласия о точном месте начала руки Ориона, большинство ученых соглашаются, что рука начинается с продолжения руки Стрельца во внешнем направлении. Изображено ниже:

Мотив созвездий-неба. Как предполагает Останин, может также относиться к говорящему коню Ариону, еще одному сыну Посейдона (Ostanin 61). Арионом также был поэт, которому посвящено стихотворение Пушкина “Арион” (1827).

intertextuality intratextuality motif foreign
мироколице

Neologism: world (мир) + outskirts (околоца).

Неологизм: мир + околоца.

neologism
созвездье

Characters turn into entire constellations. Constellation-heavens motif.

Герои превращаются в целые созвездия.

explanatory symbol motif character
Бобылки

Colloquial: an unmarried, lonely (peasant) woman. She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

Разговорное: незамужняя, одинокая женщина-крестьянка. Она встречается далее в романе и обычно ассоциируется с Ориной.

character register/style
Инспектора

That is, the inspector Pozhilykh.

То есть, инспектор Пожилых.

character
Запойный Охотник

That is, Yakov.

То есть, Яков.

character
заводной

Colloquial: lively, full of piss and vinegar.

Разговорное: задорный, веселый.

register/style
бузотер

Low: troublemaker, trickster, hellraiser.

Просторечное: хулиган, проказник, склочник.

register/style
жаждой неугасимой

Yakov, of course, is the “binging hunter.”

Яков, конечно же, “запойный охотник”.

theme
исключительной до кимрских образцовых слюз включительно

Antithetical paronomasia (isklyuchitel’noi - vklyuchitel’no).

Антитетическая парономазия (исключительной - включительно).

sound stylistic device
кимрских

A city in the Tver Oblast of Russia.

Город в Тверской области в России. Изображено ниже:

Russia location
кимрских образцовых слюз

Boguslawski writes: “The narrator refers to the celebrated sluices on the canal linking the Volga and the Moskva” (“Annotations” 244). The canal opened in 1937 after years of labor by prisoners.

Богуславкий пишет: “Рассказчик имеет в виду знаметые шлюзы, соединяющие реки Волгу и Москву” (Boguslawski “Annotations” 244). Канал был открыт в 1937 году спустя годы труда каторжников.

Russia
слюз

Dialectical/dated: sluice. Ostanin links this word to the Dutch sluis (sluice), a water or flood gate (61).

Диалектическое/устаревшее: шлюз. Останин связывает это слово с голландским sluis (шлюз), камера с воротами на канале (Ostanin 61).

register/style foreign
Не превратно ль, доказывает, вино сего года в старую бочку лить, разорвет оно ее по всем швам, искорёжит вещь и, что обиднее, само вытечет

A reference to the parable of new wine into old wineskins found in Luke 5:36–39: “And he spake also a parable unto them; No man putteth a piece of a new garment upon an old; if otherwise, then both the new maketh a rent, and the piece that was taken out of the new agreeth not with the old. And no man putteth new wine into old bottles; else the new wine will burst the bottles, and be spilled, and the bottles shall perish.” This line has entered the Slavic canon also thanks to the “Sermon of Law and Grace” attributed to Hilarion (XI century), where we read: “Ибо не вливают, по словам Господним, вина учения нового, благодатного в мехи ветхие, обветшавшие в иудействе: прорываются мехи, и вино вытекает.” On another level, this line is suggestive of Sokolov’s approach to art. That is, new forms (proetry, for example) are necessary to express new content, much as Between Dog and Wolf challenges readers with its innovative style and form. Of course, pairing Yakov (the Drunken Huntsman) with Hilarion is a debatable and possibly ironic choice. In an interview with Ivan Podshivalov, Sokolov said the following regarding Alexander Solzhenitsyn: “Solzhenitsyn tries: He writes; he makes an effort to keep pace with new literary current. He obviously takes pains to adopt new forms, assimilate avant-garde devices, but none of that suits him. Is it possible to pour new wine into old wineskins” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 356). On the subject of “proetry” and genre, Sokolov had the following to say: “Genres boundaries have eroded, and there is not need to reestablish them. The time has come for a new period of synthesis. As I explained genre interests me less than the kinds of works I write. I create proetry (proezia). This term is my discovery. Although, of course, I am far from being the first, and, more likely, I am the last in a long line of followers of the tradition that includes Turgenev and Bunin. Earlier, there were verses in prose, yet it remained prose. I think of myself as a proet” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 352). Elsewhere, however, Sokolov has expressed a view that underscores literary lineage: “For me language is a kind of symphony, and it works out that I’m writing variations on its themes. I don’t think that in principle something new comes out of it. You can only dream of something new. Anyone who writes is limited by the nature of speech” (Litus, “Snezhnyi” 382). On the use of poetry in prose, see Artem Skvortsov’s article “Iavivshiesia v inom oblichii: o poezii v proze.”

Отсылка к притче о новом вине, наливаемом в старые мехи, которую можно прочитать в Луки 5:36-39: “При сем сказал им притчу: никто не приставляет заплаты к ветхой одежде, отодрав от новой одежды; а иначе и новую раздерет, и к старой не подойдет заплата от новой. И никто не вливает молодого вина в мехи ветхие; а иначе молодое вино прорвет мехи, и само вытечет, и мехи пропадут”. Эти строки вошли в славянский канон также благодаря “Слову о законе и благодати”, приписываемому Илариону (XI век), где мы читаем: “Ибо не вливают, по словам Господним, вина учения нового, благодатного в мехи ветхие, обветшавшие в иудействе: прорываются мехи, и вино вытекает”. В то же время, в этих строках можно проследить подход Соколова к искусству. Новые литературные формы (к примеру, проезия) необходимы для выражения нового содержания, подобно тому, как Между собакой и волком бросает вызов читателю своим инновационным стилем и формой. Конечно, сравнение Якова (Запойного Охотника) с Иларионом кажется сомнительным и в некоторой степени ироническим решением. В интервью с И. Подшиваловым, Соколов говорит следующее по поводу А. Солженицына: “Солженицын старается: он пишет; он прилагает все усилия, чтобы идти в ногу с новым литературным движением. Он явно не безболезненно внедряет новые формы, ассимилирует авангардные литературные приемы, но ничто из этого ему не подходит. Можно ли вливать молодое вино в мехи ветхие?” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 356). На тему “проезии” и жанра Соколов придерживается следующего мнения: “Границы между жанрами прогнили, и нет нужды их восстанавливать. Пришло время эпохи созидания. Как я объяснил ранее, жанр интересует меня меньше работ, которые я пишу. Я создаю проезию. Этот термин — мое открытие. Хотя, конечно, я далек от звания первопроходца и, скорее, занимаю одну из последних позиции в долгой череде последователей традиций в том числе Тургенева и Бунина. Ранее, строфы встречались и в прозе, но они оставались прозой. Я считаю себя проэтом” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 352). В другом месте, однако, Соколов скептически высказался о развитии литературных направлений: “Для меня язык — своего рода симфония, а я лишь пишу вариации на его тему. Не думаю, что из него может в принципе выйти нечто новое. О новом можно лишь мечтать. Любой писатель ограничен самой природой речи” (Litus, “Snezhnyi 382).

intertextuality character bible religion self-reference
искорёжит

Low: to warp, bend out of shape.

Просторечное: повредить, исковеркать, покоробить.

register/style
не про нас, не про нашу

Syntactical repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm sound
не про нашу Заитильщину небогатую он

As often happens in the novel (since its very title), phraseologisms and metaphors are both taken as such, and as sentences referring to concrete, real phenomena. Elena Kravchenko argues that “Sokolov’s texts are not a denial of the real, but an acknowledgement of its insufficiency. Both School for Fools and Between Dog and Wolf speak about how the world contains barely anything of what we value in it. […] Working within a complex network of reflections, Sokolov offers reality his (writing) hand. For, in order for it to become a meaningful event, reality requires mediation” (The Prose 130).

Как это нередко встречается в романе (начиная с заглавия), фразеологизмы и метафоры принимают буквальное значение и относятся к реальным событиям. Е. Кравченко утверждает: “Тексты Соколова не отрицают реальность, а скорее признают ее неполноценность. Как в Школе для дураков, так и в Между собакой и волком говорится о том, как мало в мире есть того, что мы ценим. […] Работая со сложной системой отражений, Соколов предлагает реальность свою (писательскую) руку помощи. Ведь для того, чтобы реальность приобрела смысл, ей необходимен посредник” (Kravchenko “The Prose” 130).

structure explanatory
ибо

Literary/dated: because, for.

Литературное/устаревшее: потому что.

register/style
винища

A derogatory term for wine. Alcohol theme.

Пренебрежительное название для вина. Тема алкоголя.

register/style theme
раздобыть

Colloquial: to procure, get.

Разговорное: добыть, достать.

register/style
б/у

Abbreviation: бывший в употреблении (secondhand).

Аббревиатура: бывший в употреблении.

explanatory language
враз

Colloquial: at once, immediately, right off the bat.

Разговорное: одновременно, сразу.

register/style
таковские

Low: such.

Просторечное: то же, что и такой.

register/style
заплаты

A piece of fabric sewn over a torn area. Sewing theme.

Лоскут ткани, пришиваемый к порванному месту. Тема шитья.

explanatory theme
тряпью

Colloquial: old clothes, rags. Clothing motif.

Разговорное: старье, тряпки.

register/style motif
неказисто

Colloquial: unsightly, not much to look at.

Разговорное: неприглядно, некрасиво.

register/style
хламоты

Colloquial: trash.

Разговорное: то же, что хлам.

register/style
Сеял якобы сеятель

A reference to the Parable of the Sower (Matthew 13:1–23), which describes God’s message spreading. This line also refers to Bruegel’s 1557 painting of the same name,

Отсылка к Притче о сеятеле (Матфея 13:1-23), в которой описано распространение Божьего Слова. Эта фраза также относится к одноименной картине Брейгеля (1557), изображено ниже:

intertextuality bible religion
Сеял якобы сеятель

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
Рунихах

In Russia there are two rivers called Runikha, the Bol’shaya R. (Big R.) and the Malaya R. (Small R.). They both are located in the Khanty-Mansiysky region.

В России есть две реки под названием Руниха: Большая Р. и Малая Р.. Обе реки расположены в Ханты-Мансийском автономном округе.

location Russia
Лазаревом ли Поле

Sokolov affirms that this location exists on the left bank of the river Volga (personal communication, June 27, 2023).

Соколов утверждает, что данное место существует на левом берегу Волги (личная переписка, 27 июня 2023).

location Russia
Бабкина ли Креста

As Sokolov explains, “there exists a meadow called Babkin Krest (Woman’s Cross): a woman, a mushroom picker, died there, and in memory of her they placed a cross in the meadow” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет, что “существует поляна под названием Бабкин крест: там умерла какая-то грибница, и в память о ней на поляне поставили крест” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

location Russia
богаделка

A woman living in a poorhouse.

Женщина, живущая в доме для бедных.

explanatory
Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, “зимарь” — отсылка на стихотворение Андрея Вознесенского “Песенка-травести из спектакля Антимиры” (1963) (“Аннотации” 233). Образовано сочетанием слов “зима” и “январь”, подразумевая на зимнее время. Возможно, также намек на созвездие Ориона, видимое на небе в период зимнего солнцестояния. Согласно мифологии, Орион полюбил Меропу (как и многих других женщин) и насильно овладел ею, что напоминает историю Орины. Мотив созвездий-неба.

character intertextuality explanatory motif
Кондратий ее с испугу хватил

Set expression: to die suddenly. The phrase refers to the Cossack ataman Kondratii (Kondrashka) Bulavin who led an uprising in 1707–1708 in Russia. Most often this expression is used humorously to show the absurdity of a certain situation. Nowadays, the phrase is used figuratively, denoting confusion and surprise. Historian V. Solovyov suggested that the expression originated after Kondraty Bulavin’s revolt of 1707. The Don Cossack ataman organized a popular uprising, which at a certain stage was very successful. Yuri Dolgorukov (1664-1707) and his army were sent by Peter I to subdue the Cossacks. Kondraty Bulavin defeated the detachment of Dolgorukov, taking him prisoner and delivering him to a shameful execution. The protégé of Peter I had his head cut off, and a bold letter was sent to the tsar: “Kondrashka Bulavin took Dolgorukov.”

Устойчивое выражение: внезапно умереть. Фраза относится к казацкому атаману Кондратию (Кондрашке) Булавину, возглавлявшему восстание 1707–1708 годов в России. Изображен ниже:

phraseologism Russia
Постепенно находят

That is, they find her dead, piece by piece.

То есть, находят ее мертвой, по частям.

explanatory
Очи

Archaism: eyes.

Архаизм: глаза.

archaism register/style
ворон

Raven. Ravens, like crows, are associated with death, and they are frequently depicted eating eyes, as in Proverbs 30:17 and Milton’s Animadversions (Rowland, Birds 146–147). Animal motif.

theme intertextuality motif
туеске

A small rounded basket used for gathering foods.

Небольшой круглый короб для хранения пищевых продуктов. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
Сеятель

A reference to the Parable of the Sower (Matthew 13:1–23), which describes God’s message spreading. T. V. Kazarina reads this passage as part of Sokolov’s (dis)engagement with ethical questions: “The imperative, the motivation of the parable, which always directly tells one how to live, what is required of a person, has been lost. Dzyndzyrella even deduced from it that nothing is required, everything will work out by itself, things will work out, it’ll pan out. An ethical system, which varies ideas about duty and mutual obligations, turns everyone into a kind of plaintiffs and defendants, and life into a lawsuit with corresponding psychological discomfort” (192). This line also refers to Bruegel’s 1557 painting of the same name,

Отсылка к Притче о сеятеле (Матфея 13:1-23), в которой описано распространение Божьего Слова. Эта фраза также относится к одноименной картине Брейгеля (1557), изображено ниже:

intertextuality bible religion
чертополох

Carduus. Plant motif.

Род растений. Изображено ниже:

explanatory motif
кречет

Gyrfalcon. Animal motif.

Птица из семейства соколиных. Изображено ниже:

Мотив животных.

motif
коршун

Kite. The kite has largely been associated with greed (Aristophanes, Plautus), tyranny (Dante), gluttony (John Gower), and death and violence (Shakespeare) (Rowland, Birds 93–94). The birds in this scene greedily collect the Sower’s seeds. Animal motif.

Птица из семейства ястребиных. Изображено ниже: Мотив животных.

motif intertextuality
перепела

Quail. According to Beryl Rowland, the quail has been equated with salacious women (Birds 140). “The erotic significance,” Rowland continues, “dates from ancient times, when the bird was a symbol of generation and rebirth. Latona, the goddess who gave birth to Artemis and Apollo at Delos, regarded the bird as her own: the Phoenician Hercules, whose death and resurrection were commemorated annually, was revived when the quail, a bird ‘noted for its pugnacity and lechery,’ was held to his nose. The same significance may explain the story of the migrating quails in Exodus xvi.13 and Numbers xi.33-34. […] In the ninth century Rabanus Maurus, Archbishop of Mainz, in commenting on the passage, declared, “by quail is meant the pleasures of the body” (141). Alternatively, Peter Tate writes that quails have been associated with Biblical plagues, the taste of their flesh and eggs, unwholesomeness, and medicinal qualities (107–108). The birds in this scene greedily collect the Sower’s seeds. Animal motif.

Птица из семейства фазановых. Изображено ниже:

motif folklore religion Bible
продовольствоваться

Dated: to feed on, be nourished on.

Устаревшее: питаться.

register/style
с грехом пополам

Set expression: with great difficulty/pains.

Устойчивое выражение: с большим трудом.

phraseologism
ни с того ни с сего

Set expression: all of a sudden, out of the blue.

Устойчивое выражение: неожиданно.

register/style phraseologism
ту книгу

The Gospels.

Евангелие.

religion bible intertextuality
перемелется

From the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.

От выражения: “Всё перемелется — мука будет”. Выражение темы мельницы в романе. Соколов неоднократно обыгрывает это выражение и созвучность муки (страдания) и муки (хлебопекарной).

theme intratextuality phraseologism
Не волнуйтесь

Since Ilya’s letter is addressed to Pozhilykh, he might indeed wonder whether his “constellation” will also be mentioned.

Так как письмо Ильи адресовано Пожилых, он, должно быть, ожидает, что и его созвездие будет упомянуто.

explanatory
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality religion
локтя

An outdated Russian unit of measurement equal to approximately 54 centimeters (21 inches).

Устаревшая русская длина меры, эквивалентная примерно 54 сантиметрам (21 дюймам).

Russia
Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, “зимарь” — отсылка на стихотворение Андрея Вознесенского “Песенка-травести из спектакля Антимиры” (1963) (“Аннотации” 233). Образовано сочетанием слов “зима” и “январь”, подразумевая на зимнее время. Возможно, также намек на созвездие Ориона, видимое на небе в период зимнего солнцестояния. Согласно мифологии, Орион полюбил Меропу (как и многих других женщин) и насильно овладел ею, что напоминает историю Орины. Мотив созвездий-неба.

explanatory intertextuality character motif
светляков

Stars are compared to fireflies. Once again insects appear in the novel.

Звезды сравниваются со светлячками. В романе вновь появляются насекомые.

motif
светляков Вы. Тот же светит,

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
фингал

Low: shiner, black eye.

Просторечное: синяк под глазом.

register/style
Егерь

That is, Yakov.

То есть, Яков.

character explanatory
в обычных летах

Set expression: в летах (getting on in years).

Устойчивое выражение: в летах (пожилой).

phraseologism
Оспа

Smallpox.

Вид вирусной инфекции.

explanatory
Оспа портрет ему слегка изменила, еще — дробью охота его потратила, нос — морозом, вином нажгла, а лис ему бешеный ухо отгрыз: понимаем ту бабушку

He is definitively not good-looking.

Он явно не отличается привлекательностью.

character explanatory
Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

character intertextuality explanatory motif
Даниилы

A reference to D. Zatochnika (Д. Заточника) near the beginning of chapter 1. Metonymy: his companions at the artel.

Отсылка к артели имени Д. Заточника, упоминавшейся в начале главы 1. Менонимия: здесь употредлено в значении его товарищей по артели.

intertextuality intratextuality
Гурием

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
Илья

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
Илья Дзынзырэлла

Ilya frequently refers to himself in the third person.

Илья часто обращается к себе в третьем лице.

explanatory
Дзынзырэлла

Another variation on Ilya’s unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356).

Вновь, необычная фамилия Илья (которая встречается более 10 раз и в других графических-орфографических вариантах дальше в тексте). Намекается на сказку Золушки (по-английски Cinderella; cм. L. Toker, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356).

intertextuality character
отхожей местности

Colloquial: an outhouse.

Разговорное: туалет.

register/style phraseologism
ракушек

Ilya also writes about mussels at the end of chapter 1 (R157–158/E16). Associated with sex and Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

Илья касается темы ракушек в конце главы 1 (R157–158/E16). Ассоциируются с сексом и Ориной.

Эмблема Святого Иакова Великого напоминает раковину моллюска. Изображено ниже: Мотив животных.

intratextuality symbol theme motif bible religion
Всюду сумерки, всюду вечер

Between dog and wolf.

Между собакой и волком.

theme
Всюду сумерки, всюду вечер, везде Итиль

Syntactical repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
Всюду сумерки, всюду вечер, везде Итиль. Но там, где Зимарь-Человек телегой скрипит — заосеняло с небес, у коллег в Городнище завьюжило, а на моей Волка-речке — иволга да желна

A version of this entire passage appears in chapter 10 (R222/E127).

Вариация этого отрывка встречается в главе 10 (R222/E127).

intratextuality
Итиль

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

Татарское название Волги. Заглавие письма Ильи “Заитильщина” является производным от этой версии названия реки. Остатин также указывает на фонетическое сходство рек Итиль и Леты, реки забытья, которая также играет важную роль в первом романе Соколова “Школа для дураков” (Ostanin 10).

location foreign language setting
Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, “зимарь” — отсылка на стихотворение Андрея Вознесенского “Песенка-травести из спектакля Антимиры” (1963) (“Аннотации” 233). Образовано сочетанием слов “зима” и “январь”, подразумевая на зимнее время. Возможно, также намек на созвездие Ориона, видимое на небе в период зимнего солнцестояния. Согласно мифологии, Орион полюбил Меропу (как и многих других женщин) и насильно овладел ею, что напоминает историю Орины. Мотив созвездий-неба.

character explanatory intertextuality motif
заосеняло

Dated/poetic: to fall upon, spread, cover, dawn upon.

register/style
заосеняло с небес

Another instance of the rising/falling theme.

Очередной пример темы падения/восхождения.

theme
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов “город” и “нищий”. Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: “Если Школа для дураков была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, Между собакой и волком можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых” (Matich “Sasha Sokolov” 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid “Zaitil’shchina” 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson “Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

location setting intertextuality folklore theme
Волка-речке

The Volga river assonates with volk (wolf) and here is interpolated with the adjective volciia, generating Volka-rechka.

intratextuality sound play
Волка-речке — иволга

This paronomastic couple (Volga - ivolga) occurs again. However, here with a variation: Volka.

Снова в романе повторяется пара “Волга - иволга”, здесь с вариацией “Волка”.

sound stylistic device
иволга

Eurasian golden oriole. Animal motif.

Птица из отряда воробьинообразных. Изображено ниже:

Мотив животных.

motif
иволга да желна

These two birds are paired together in chapter 10, where Ilya picks up certain narrative threads (R207/E100). Animal motif.

Между этими двумя птицами проводится параллель в главе 10, где Илья продолжает определенные сюжетные линии (R207/E100). Мотив животных.

intratextuality motif
желна

Black woodpecker. The woodpecker has traditionally played roles “as the god-sent bird in the ancient sacred grove; as the bird who […] cared for Romulus and Remus, and as the oracular bird of Mars, god of war” (Rowland, Birds 180). The black woodpecker in particular in folklore is often depicted as a “villain” who “acts contrary to the commands of the Almighty” in refusing to help create the world (Armstrong 96). Furthermore, “in a Russian legend, the woodpecker is a man whom God changed into a bird because he worked on Sunday” (97). Animal motif.

motif symbol
Поступаю, как старшая велит, и вступаю

Verbal repetition with different prefix.

Повтор глаголов с разными приставками.

rhythm sound
суму переметную

This phraseologism is generally used to describe a person with an unstable character. However, the syntagm refers to a folding bag (made of fabric or leather) used to transport things on a horse. This type of bag is also linked with the tradition of bylina, in particular with the character of Svyatogor-bogatyr’. Here is the bylina in Russian, and in its English translation. It is mentioned also in ch. 4 (R176/E48) and it will be mentioned again in ch. 8 (R207/E100) and 12 (R247/E170).

Этот фразеологизм обычно используется для описания человека непостоянного и непоследовательного. Однако, в этом контексте относится к седловой сумке (из ткани или кожи), используемой для траспортировки грузов на лошади. Изображено ниже: Такой тип сумки тесно связан с былинами, в частности, с персонажемем Святогора-богатыря. Прочитать былину на русском можно здесь, а английский перевод — здесь. Упоминается в главах 4 (R176/E48), 8 (R207/E100) и 12 (R247/E170).

intertextuality intratextuality phraseologism explanatory
битком

Colloquial expression: chock-full, to the gills.

Разговорное выражение: по предела.

phraseologism register/style
мастера в декабре под горой гудят

Yakov suggests that he sees Bruegel’s painting outside his window. A central motif in the novel, this phrase alludes to The Hunters in the Snow, a 1565 painting by Pieter Bruegel the Elder. The setting and action of this image recurs throughout Between Dog and Wolf (e.g., R202–203/E93–95), as they come to life in the text. Elena Kravchenko explains: “Besides the ‘trope’ of the exhibition viewing, the device of ekphrasis, and the ‘gallery’ structure of The Pictures, Sokolov borrows the underlying ‘teleology’ of Musorgskii’s work. Alongside Borodin, Balakirev, Cui, and Rimskii Korsakov, Musorgskii was one of the ‘Mighty Handful’ (‘Moguchaia kuchka’). Created under the patronage of an art critic Vladimir Stasov, it became the hub of a pioneering national style which espoused folklore and the traditions of the peasantry as the new foundation for Russian music. The group was closely connected with and drew inspiration from the Wanderers, an artistic movement […] Iakov is set to communicate a similar idea. He comes to the Volga to grasp and represent the lives of its people. Besides his poetic gift, Iakov is an artist, and it is his works that form the textual gallery of the prose chapters. The gallery ‘entries’ are either demarcated graphically with italics, which signals a title of a painting, or framed by a reference to their pictorial ‘origin’” (The Prose 61). She continues: “It can be argued that Iakov’s representation of human suffering, which constitutes one of the main themes of the novel, and which has been identified as the major moral message of many Brueghel paintings, is modelled not directly on Brueghel but on W. H. Auden’s ekphrasis in his ‘Musée des Beaux Arts’. Running through the images of Brueghel’s The Census at Bethlehem (1566) and The Slaughter of the Innocents (ca. 1564), it culminates in the ekphrasis of Landscape with the Fall of Icarus (ca. 1558)” (The Prose 63). On the presence and role of Bruegel’s imagery and subtext, see also Mario Caramitti’s article “Mul’tfilmy Breigelia.” Beyond these obvious ekphrastic connections between Sokolov’s novel and Bruegel’s painting, these are other points worth noting. For instance, the series from which Hunters in the Snow derives, The Seasons (1565) is divided into six paintings, five of which remain extant. “If a division of the year into six pictures seems strange initially,” Sabine Pénot and Elke Oberthaler write, “this proves to have been a common way of diving the annual cycle in the Netherlands during the period, as early spring and spring and early summer and midsummer were differentiated. The year’s inherently cyclic character relativizes the discussion around the ‘correct’ order of the pictures – which painting represents the beginning and which the end of the series” (214). Much the same may be said about the structure of Between Dog and Wolf, in which the poetic chapters trace the development of seasonal changes, while everything exists in an in-between state (seasons, characters’ identities, etc.). It is also worth noting that, as in Sokolov’s text where strict adherence to geographical reality is not observed, the landscapes depicted in the Seasons paintings are not accurate: “These so-called ‘mixed landscapes’ combine memories of the Alps with typically Flemish motifs” (229). There is something to be said about the way Sokolov, like Bruegel develops a “sheer inexhaustible richness of detail” that inevitably leads to “the limits of visual perception and linguistic representation” (215). One particular detail of the painting, apparently not described by Sokolov in the novel, feels relevant: “Thick icicles have claimed the mill wheel at the right edge and brought it to a halt, as though time itself has frozen” (228). Indeed, time and therefore the characters feel stuck in the world of Between Dog and Wolf.

Скорее всего, относится к картине Брейгеля, встречавшейся в экфрастическом описании Якова “Охотников на снегу”, написанную в 1565 году картину Питера Брейгеля Старшего, ведь когда картина впервые встречается в романе, Яков упоминает декабрь. Сцена из картины повторяется на протяжении “Между собакой и волком” например, R202–203/E93–95), будто бы оживая на страницах романа. Изображено ниже:

Е. Кравченко объясняет: “Помимо метафоры посещения художественной выставки, приема экфрасиса и “галерейной” структуры Картинок, Соколов заимствует основополагающую телеологию творчества Мусоргского. Наравне с Бородиным, Балакиревым, Кюи и Римским-Корсаковым, Мусоргский относился к “Могучей кучке”. Созданная под патронажем художественного критика В. Стасова, группа стала эпицентром развития нового национального стиля русской музыки, в основе которого лежали крестьянские традиции и фольклор. Могучая кучка была тесно связана и черпала вдохновение у художественного движения Передвижников […]. Яков намерен передать ту же идею. Он поселяется на Волге, чтобы запечатлить и отобразить жизнь тамошних людей. Помимо поэтического дара, Яков также наделен художественным талантом, и это его работы формируют словесную галерею прозаических глав. “Экспонаты” галереи или графически выделены курсивом, то есть, относятся к названию картины, или определяются отсылкой к “прототипу” образа” (Kravchenko, “The Prose” 61). Она продолжает: “Можно предположить, что изображение Яковом человеческого страдания, что является одной из главных тем романа и что было определено как одно из центральных моральных посылов картин Брейгеля, строится не напрямую на Брейгеле, а на экфрасисе У. Одена в его “Музее изящных искусств”. Останавливаясь на “Переписи в Вифлееме” Брейгеля (1566) и “Избиении младенцев” (пр. 1564), экфрасис достигает кульминации в описании “Падения Икара” (пр. 1558)” (Kravchenko, “The Prose” 63). О присутствии и роли образов и подтекстов Брейгеля можно прочитать в статье М. Карамитти “Мультифильмы Брейгеля” (Caramitti “Mul’tfilmy Breigelia”).

intratextuality intertextuality structure foreign
гудят

Colloquial: to revel, buzz, party.

Разговорное: шуметь, праздновать, громко разговаривать.

register/style
Петра

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality religion foreign
Егор

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10), имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных “е/ё” и “о”.

character explanatory intratextuality foreign religion
сидням

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяи, бездельники.

register/style
на́ косу

Set expression: ходить на кос (to ask for cigarettes).

Отмель или мыс, а также сплетенные пряди волос или орудие для кошения травы. См. также “Балаганчик” А. Блока. “Ходить на косу” также может употребляться в значении “просить сигарет”.

phraseologism
косу

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

theme intertextuality language
той дамы

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
хоть вешайся

It becomes a pattern that men who spend time with the Dame return depleted and soon after commit suicide.

То, что мужчины возвращаются истощенными и совершают самоубийство вскоре после проведенного с Дамой времени, становится закономерностью.

theme
вешайся. Те утешать

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
Те утешать: повеситься ты всегда успеешь, спорить лучше давай.

This conversation and the hunters’ dare to Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr to hang himself after his time with the Dame is picked up in chapter 10 (R222/E127–128) and also appears in Note XXXI (R268/E208).

Этот разговор и брошенный охотниками Егору/Федору/Петру вызов повеситься после проведенного им с Дамой времени продолжается в главе 10 (R222/E127–128) и встречается снова в Записке XXXI (R268/E208).

intratextuality explanatory
спорить лучше давай. Спорить так спорить

Repetition.

Повтор.

sound rhythm
Петр

The name changes back to Pyotr. Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Имя вновь меняется на Петр.

character religion intratextuality foreign
заядлый

Colloquial: inveterate, hardcore, enthusiastic.

Разговорное: закоренелый, завзятый, с увлечением отдающийся какому-нибудь занятию.

register/style
Вышелбауши

A reference to the expression “Выше лба уши не растут” meaning that one has limits to what they can do.

Отсылка к выражению “Выше лба уши не растут”, означающему, что невозможно сделать более того, на что способен.

phraseologism
лесопильный

Mentioned by the narrator in the next chapter (R213/E111).

Упоминается рассказчиком в следующей главе (R213/E111).

intratextuality
пари

Betting; an agreement to pay a certain amount of money or transfer other property by one (losing) party to the other (winning) party, based on a conflict of predictions or a dispute. They are now betting that he will not hung himself.

Спор: соглашение заплатить определенную сумму денег или передать иного рода имущество проигравшего лица выигравшему лицу, основанное на разногласии вышеупомянутых лиц. Охотники спорят, что он не повесится.

explanatory
спроворить

Colloquial: to filch, steal.

Разговорное: стащить, украсть.

register/style
балясину

Изображено ниже:

explanatory
спроворить

Colloquial: to filch, steal.

Разговорное: стащить, украсть.

register/style
удавиться

Colloquial: to hang oneself.

Разговорное: повеситься.

register/style
удушишься

Low: to hang oneself.

Просторечное: то же, что удавиться.

register/style
кишка тонка

Set expression: ain’t got the guts, lily-livered, to lack the intestinal fortitude.

Устойчивое выражение: о недостатке силы, способностей, средств для осуществления чего-либо.

register/style phraseologism
Это сидни Петру на косе говорили, это они, сидни, твердили Федору

Rhetorical repetition of the sentence.

Риторический повтор фразы.

rhythm stylistic device
сидни

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяи, бездельники.

register/style
Петру

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intratextuality
косе

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

Отмель или мыс, а также сплетенные пряди волос или орудие для кошения травы. См. также “Балаганчик” А. Блока.

theme intertextuality language
сидни

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяи, бездельники.

register/style
Федору

The name changes, yet again, to Fyodor. Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Имя в который раз меняется на Федор.

character explanatory foreign religion intratextuality
Федору, а у Ильи дело к ужину

Rhyme (Fyodoru - uzhinu).

rhyme rhythm
Ильи

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
ракушки

Ilya also writes about mussels at the end of chapter 1 (R157–158/E16). Associated with sex and Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

Илья касается темы ракушек в конце главы 1 (R157–158/E16). Ассоциируются с сексом и Ориной.

Эмблема Святого Иакова Великого напоминает раковину моллюска. Изображено ниже: Мотив животных.

theme symbol intratextuality motif religion bible
Скис

Colloquial: to lose heart, calm, become depressed.

Разговорное: упасть духом, впасть в уныние.

register/style
соловей

Nightingale. According to Peter Tate: “A small member of the warbler family, which has russet upper parts, a broad tail, and is grey-brown below. Its preferred habitat is deciduous woods with dense undergrowth. It is notable for its beautiful song whose notes rise and fall in succession. Contrary to popular belief, nightingales don’t just sing at night, but their song is more difficult to distinguish in daylight hours owing to competition from other birds and everyday ambient noise” (81). José Vergara writes: “the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family” (“Flap” 364–365). The characters of Sokolov’s novel play out this plot with Ilya seeking out his missing lover Orina and their son Yakov. Animal-human motif.

motif intertextuality
ужовниках
