Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
аванец

Part of salary.

Аванс - часть зарплаты.

explanatory
гуляй

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina will be defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

Разговорное: развлекаться, отдыхать. Частое употребление глагола “гулять” связано с определением Орины в главе 10 как “гулящей”: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). В данном случае, “гулена” относится к пристрастию Орины к застольям и пиршествам, а “гулящая” указывает на ее беспорядочные романтические отношения.

intratextuality register/style
гуляй, рванина

Ostanin explains that this suggests the possibility of living one’s entire life on little money (65). He also notes a borrowing from Vladimir Vysotsky’s song “Penal Battalions.” Read the lyrics in the original and in English translation here.

explanatory intertextuality music
рванина

Colloquial: scoundrel, jerk.

Разговорное: негодяй, мерзавец.

register/style
в те хитрые годы

See also Chapter 6 (R194/E78).

См. главу 6.

intratextuality
в те хитрые годы как годы трактир — не трактир, лабаз — не лабаз

Repetitions.

Повторы.

rhythm sound
лабаз

Dated: shop, lean-to.

Устаревшее: сарай, продовольственный магазин.

register/style
лабаз

Dated: shop, lean-to.

Устаревшее: сарай, продовольственный магазин.

register/style
забегаловка

Colloquial: low-quality snack bar, eatery.

Разговорное: столовая или закусочная, обычно не очень высокого качества.

register/style location
рукой подать

Set expression: within walking distance, a stone’s throw away.

Устойчивое выражение: очень близко, совсем рядом.

phraseologism
ближе близкого

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
фрамугами

Transom windows — windows located above a door with a crossbar separating the two parts used to provide ventilation.

Фрамуга — горизонтальная верхняя глухая часть окна, боковая или верхняя часть проема двери. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
тракт

Dated: high road, large road, highway.

Устаревшее: шоссе, большая проезжая дорога.

register/style
Отоварились

Colloquial: to get/buy necessary goods.

Разговорное: покупать/добывать необходимые вещи.

register/style
акациях

Acacia trees. A self-reference to Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, in which the character Vetka Acacia appears: “как твое имя меня называют Веткой я Ветка акации я Ветка железной дороги я Вета беременная от ласковой птицы по имени Найтингейл я беременна будущим летом и крушением товарняка” (whats your name I am called Vetka [Branch] I am Vetka of the acacia I am Vetka of the railroad I am Veta pregnant by the tender bird named Nightingale I am pregnant with the coming summer and the crash of the freight train) (Shkola R11/E12). There is thus a confluence of motifs here: trains, plants, sex. Ernst and Johanna Lehner write that the acacia is “native to Egypt” and “called by the Israelites the Shittah-tree. They carried the wood of this tree in their exodus from Egypt through the desert, and later built their Tabernacle and the Arc of the Covenant from this wood to atone for their crime committed at Shittin. The wood of the acacia was considered sacred by the Hebrews” (23). Furthermore, the thorny crown of Jesus was allegedly made from acacia according to sources from the Middle East (23). Plant motif.

Дерево акации. Мотив растений. Самоссылка на первый роман Соколова, Школа для дураков, где появляется героиня Ветка Акация: “как твое имя меня называют Веткой я Ветка акации я Ветка железной дороги я Вета беременная от ласковой птицы по имени Найтингейл я беременна будущим летом и крушением товарняка” (Школа ###). Здесь происходит слияние нескольких мотивов: поезда, растения, секс.

self-reference motif intertextuality
дреме

Meadow grass belonging to the clove family with a sticky stem and red flowers. Plant motif.

Луговая трава из семейства гвоздичных с клейким стеблем и красными цветами. Изображено ниже:

Мотив растений.

motif
лапсердак

A frock coat or long black kaftan worn by Jewish men. Also a poorly-sewed coat. Clothing motif.

Верхнее длиннополое платье у польских и галицких евреев, сюртук особого покроя. Нелепая, плохо сшитая одежда. Мотив одежды.

explanatory motif
таранька азовская вяленая

Roach. Served as a dried snack with drinks. Animal motif.

Сушеная рыба. Подается как сухая закуска к напиткам. Мотив животных-рыб. Изображено ниже:

motif
Спели, попели

Verbal repetition with different prefixes.

Повтор глагола с разными приставками.

sound rhythm
замолаживало

Dialectical: to cover with clouds, become overcast.

Диалектическое: заволакиваться тучами, облаками (о небе).

register/style
достали

Colloquial: to deeply annoy.

Разговорное: сильно надоесть.

register/style
достали

Colloquial: to deeply annoy.

Разговорное: сильно надоесть.

register/style
квакухи

Frogs. Animal motif.

motif
Мыслил я тучи вспять завернуть

An apparent reference to Ilya’s connection to the prophet Elijah and his mastery over thunder, clouds, rain, and so on.

Очевидная отсылка к связи Ильи с пророком Илией и его властью над громом, дождем, тучами и т. п.

intertextuality religion
вспять

Literary: backward.

Литературное: назад.

register/style
назюзился

Low: to get drunk. Alcohol theme.

Просторечное: напился.

register/style theme
скрытная вода в облацех

A variation of the set expression “темна вода во облацех,” meaning something we hardly comprehend, that is obscure.

Вариация выражения “темна вода во облацех”, то есть, что-либо непонятное и необъяснимое.

phraseologism
авось

Colloquial: maybe, perhaps, possibly.

Разговорное: наверное, может быть станется, сбудется.

register/style
Ан

Low: but no, on the contrary, but in fact.

Просторечное: но нет, напротив, на самом деле.

register/style
пристигло

Dated: to catch unawares, befall.

Устаревшее: застать врасплох, настигнуть.

register/style
влечет

Dated: to pull, drag.

Устаревшее: манить, тянуть.

register/style
Там карбас перевернутый ничейный на гальке валялся ничком

This scene is mentioned by Ilya in chapter 14 (R256–257/E189).

Эта сцена упоминается Ильей в главе 14 (R256–257/E189).

intratextuality
карбас

Dialectical: karbass, a medium rowing and fishing sailboat. Alexander Boguslawski suggests that this word is “a typical spoonerism, a slip of the tongue, which results in reversal of letters or syllables. […] the narrator (Il’ia) has in mind the word barkas” (“How Sokolov’s” 210). Boat motif.

Диалектическое: парусно-гребное промысловое и транспортное судно среднего размера. Изображено ниже: А. Богуславский предполагает, что это слово — “типичный спунеризм, оговорка, в результате чего несколько слогов или букв меняются местами”. […] рассказчик (Илья) имел в виду слово баркас” (Boguslawski “How Sokolov’s 210). Мотив лодки.

motif
ничейный

Low: no one’s, abandoned.

Просторечное: ничей.

register/style
ничейный на гальке валялся ничком

Alliteration (nich).

Аллитерация (нич).

sound stylistic device
валялся

Colloquial: to lie about, be strewn about.

Разговорное: лежать.

register/style
рогатина

A bear spear. Used in hunting and battle. Built to hook into an animal’s body to maintain a proper distance during combat.

Использовавшееся в старину тяжёлое копьё для рукопашного боя или для охоты на крупного зверя. Смоделировано таким образом, что может впиваться в животное, при этом сохраняя безопасную дистанцию между охотником и животным. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
кремень

Flint.

Разновидность кремнезёма, очень твёрдый минерал.

explanatory
огниво

Firesteel.

Кусок камня или металла, используемый для получения огня путём высекания искр соударением о кремень.

explanatory
папиросных

A cigarette with a paper mouthpiece, typically without a filter.

Сигареты с бумажной гильзой, обычно без фильтра. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
сварганился

Colloquial: to whip up, get together, do.

Разговорное: появиться, загореться.

register/style
Орину

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Илью

Ilya frequently refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

Илья часто обращается к себе в третьем лице.

explanatory intertextuality folklore character
Шел бабай по стене, нес семеро лаптей, и себе, и жене, и дитенку по лаптенку

A Russian nursery rhyme “used to make children aware of their body (spine); as used here, it may indicate intimate contact between Orina and Ilya” (Boguslawski “Annotations” 245). The original goes: “Шел Бай по стене, / Нес лапти в кошеле. Детишкам по лаптишкам, / И себе, и жене.”

Детский стишок: “Шел Бай по стене, / Нес лапти в кошеле. Детишкам по лаптишкам, / И себе, и жене.”

intertextuality explanatory theme
бабай

In Slavic folklore, the bogeyman. Descriptions vary but often he is disabled in some manner: mute, lame, or missing an arm. Used to scare children who misbehave or refuse to sleep. The name is derived from the Tatar for “grandfather” or “old man.”

intertextuality intratextuality foreign folklore
лаптей

Bast shoes. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
дитенку

Colloquial: kid, child.

register/style
лаптенку

Bast shoes. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
Хлынь

Heavy rain.

language
ветоши

Described in chapter 10 (R220, 222/E124, 126).

intratextuality
Посвятил

High: to familiarize, inform.

register/style
Посвятил ты меня в свои случаи, подруга мне говорит, а желаешь — и я тебе что-либо поведаю.

This narrative—a switch to Orina’s point of view—will be picked up at the beginning of chapter 10 (R218/E121).

explanatory intratextuality character
поведаю

Dated/literary: to tell, recount.

register/style
